author: sky.cactus
content: This is a form of KYC/AML, and it violates people's privacy.  It makes it so someone who is not comfortable giving out their cell phone number to a an untrusted centralized party is unable to interact with the system.  i.e., a barrier to entry that reduces the total set of people who *can*/*are willing* to interact with the system.

However simswapping / simjacking exists, and it might be far easier for someone connected/affiliated with a service provider. Of the past 48 months I've spent over 30 without a cellphone, so I personally wouldn't be a fan of it.

author: modernlegend.
content: why do you view people caring about whether a human is interacting with a bot (and vice versa) be a problem? Bots have very destructive properties to human coordination - e.g. bots can  be leveraged by a single human to distort legitimate social influence by flooding said human's target post with upvotes/likes. But also bots can also be used to dos a network with spam transactions, etc.  To care about our mechanics around handling bots is to care about creating a more successful human coordination system. Isn't that largely the point of this whole project?

author: sky.cactus
content: The root problem is almost always something else, and not the bot vs human thing.  For example, mis-aligned incentives.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is very rare that I see a problem where I feel the *right* solution is differentiating humans and bots.

author: modernlegend.
content: Ok, so how would you solve the social media problem of using bots to game influence?

author: potuz
content: There's a real problem in that an entity with enough funds will still find more difficult  finding humans do do their deed or to support their agenda than using a botnet. So a government system where there's a vote per person, Even if it's legal to sell it, is less prone to these attacks than a system where there's a vote per address or anything that can be impersonated by a bot

author: sky.cactus
content: What you *actually* want is a trust network.  Current social media platforms have completely failed to build such a thing.

author: sky.cactus
content: You can't blame them too much, building a human trust network is *really hard*.

author: sky.cactus
content: Humans are *incredibly susceptible to manipulation.  In todays "democracy", we already have the problem of the party with the most financial interest (most willing to spend) gets what they want.

author: sky.cactus
content: The best you can hope for is that the system is complicated enough to game that it bogs things down so change is slow.

author: modernlegend.
content:
right, so you used the term "trust network". This goes back to the question of 'how does one build trust around identity while preserving privacy'. Seems like there's just two criteria that the solution needs to meet:
1.  Identity needs to be anchored to something that's difficult to replicate en-masse (i.e. an ip address does not meet this criteria)
2. It should preserve privacy. 

The best (certainly imperfect) idea I can think of at the moment at least is a cell phone (most people have one, and it's hard to get a mass of them), and perhaps the system for registering it on the chain leverages some kind of zero knowledge technology where your privacy is still preserved. But perhaps a better solution would require the introduction of a new physical, real world asset which we would intentionally make difficult to replicate (as difficult as a birth certificate), but it would be less attached to doxing info?

author: potuz
content: This is true, but no matter how susceptible humans are, they'll never be as easy to manipulate like bots

author: sky.cactus
content:
> This goes back to the question of 'how does one build trust around identity while preserving privacy'
One can choose to trust a non-human.  I trust my dog to identify intruders more than I trust basically anyone else in the house to do so.

author: sky.cactus
content: Similarly, one may trust certain bots more than they trust humans.  A good trust network doesn't assert which actors are worth of trust, that is for the individuals in the trust network to decide.

author: sky.cactus
content: I may trust an AI news aggregator more than a CNN or Fox news anchor.

author: modernlegend.
content: I'm not sure that's a fair analogy. When you "choose" to trust any entity you're taking the risk of that entity betraying your trust. Blockchain is powerful because you don't have to 'choose' to take a risk of trust on a single entity.  Provided you accept the trust assumptions of the consensus mechanism (e.g. an honest majority of nodes), one doesn't "choose" who to trust. One accepts that the system has been designed to necessarily be trust worthy. It's not "I hope this entity doesn't betray me", it's "this entity can't betray me given this rule set"

author: modernlegend.
content: I think we've basically solved it for the "trust that a given transaction is valid" through current blockchain tech, but we haven't solved that "trust a given set of alleged identities are in fact distinct, autonomous  identities"

author: potuz
content: incentives in well designed system may be impossible to define or even if well defined they may not be quantifiable. Even assuming that everyone's incentive when they go to the ballots to chose their president is generally the same, say something like "I'm choosing the one that will bring prosperity to most in my Country", we may disagree on what prosperity is, or what are the means to achieve it. We may even dissagree on how many votes do I get to have vs how many do you have. It doesn't need to be something at that scale, whatever governance system, from the whole Ethereum ecosystem just voting in the protocol guild, whatever mechanism you choose will benefit some interests and hurt others. What is clear is that in some of these, for example all the decision making processes listed: from the national elections with one vote per citizen, through the Ethereum ecosystem with a loose governance system where technical knowledge and work done gives you a little more leverage, to the protocol guild where every voting person and he's weight is chosen beforehand, in all of them, you will not want to have one person accumulating votes. If everyone is willing to sell his vote for $10, that puts a number to a centralized entity that wants to attack this system. this is a more secure system than any system susceptible to impersonation and bots placing votes, as long as the cost of deploying these votes is less than $10 times the number of required votes. At some small scales we can rely on good sense, but this is not the case always
